question: A component named CD155 does not exist according to the given table.
A T cell expresses CD3 receptors.
The α and γ loci have V, D, and J segments in their genetic composition related to the T-cell receptor.
Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID) is induced in germinal center B cells where it plays roles in processes including both somatic mutation and class-switching of antibodies.
Dendritic cells primarily acquire antigens through passive diffusion across their membrane.
Somatic hypermutation leading to affinity maturation primarily occurs outside germinal centers in lymph nodes.
HLA-DM encodes the class II molecule DM, which loads peptides onto class II molecules.
Pentraxin-3 (PTX3) is expressed by macrophages and dendritic cells in response to IL-6.
IL-1 induces fever and sleep through lymphocyte costimulation.
T-dependent antigens do not require recognition by both T cells and B cells to elicit an antibody response.
Helper T cells are exclusively responsible for producing all types of cytokines.
IL-36 regulates MHC class II.
Lymphocytes require both antigen stimulation and a costimulatory "danger signal" to become activated.
Spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 initiates the alternative pathway.
Diapedesis involves cells passing through gaps created by dissolving the basal lamina using enzymes released by the migrating cells themselves.
Inflammation involves vasodilation, which allows decreased blood flow due to the actions of mediators such as histamine on the smooth muscle in the vessel wall.
Cell death caused by cytotoxic effector mechanisms always involves inflammation due to the release of pro-inflammatory mediators.
Transplant rejection primarily occurs through humoral immunity involving IgA antibodies.
Governments set emission standards for vehicle exhaust to limit pollutants such as PM, NOx, CO, and VOCs exclusively for diesel engines.

Up to 50% of disease susceptibility for type-1 diabetes is attributed to environmental factors.

Mice lacking the thymus exhibit defects primarily affecting their ability to produce antibodies against infections but retain functional innate immunity components including natural killer cells and macrophages.
Hemagglutination involves detecting antibodies through the agglutination of white blood cells.
Transfusion reactions always involve the activation of complement due to pre-existing antibodies against the infused blood group antigens.
